issues.fullMessage: You can't rely on garbage collection to clean up everything. Specifically, you can't count on it to release non-memory resources such as "File"s. For that, there's the "IDisposable" interface, and the contract that "Dispose" will always be called on such objects. When an "IDisposable" is a class member, then it's up to that class to call "Dispose" on it, ideally in its own "Dispose" method. If it's a local variable, then it should be instantiated with a "using" clause to prompt automatic cleanup when it goes out of scope.

You can't rely on garbage collection to clean up everything. Specifically, you can't count on it to release non-memory resources such as "File"s. For that, there's the "IDisposable" interface, and the contract that "Dispose" will always be called on such objects. When an "IDisposable" is a class member, then it's up to that class to call "Dispose" on it, ideally in its own "Dispose" method. If it's a local variable, then it should be instantiated with a "using" clause to prompt automatic cleanup when it goes out of scope.

If it's a local variable, then it should be instantiated with a "using" clause to prompt automatic cleanup when it goes out of scope.
